Award.AwardTitle: Eigenvalue Inequalities, Intersection of Schubert Varieties, and Related Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will continue the study on various problems naturally arise in operator theory and operator algebra related to the Horn's Conjecture, and their relationships to representation theory, combinatorics, and algebraic geometry. The Horn's Conjecture was originally formulated for the eigenvalues of sums of self-adjoint matrices and had shown many important connections with algebraic geometry and representation theory. So far, there were successful generalizations to the infinite dimensional settings, including compact operators on infinite dimensional Hilbert spaces and elements in finite von Neumann algebras. This work also revealed some intricate structure properties on the lattices of invariant subspaces of certain operators and properties on the algebra. This project will help to gain insights in the structure of finite von Neumann algebras and may bring new directions to representation theory and algebraic geometry.

Horn's Conjecture was formulated as a problem in linear algebra and it has natural analogues in the infinite dimensional setting and in the von Neumann algebra setting. The tools involved in solving the original Horn's Conjecture were coming from algebraic geometry, representation theory, and combinatorics. The recent advances make a compelling case to continue the investigator's collaborative effort. It is also hopeful that the insights developed here may result in new discoveries, directions and problems for algebraic geometry and representation theory. The investigator is also the ADVANCE Professor of College of Sciences at Georgia Tech, working towards a more family friendly working environment for all faculty, in particular for women and as a role model and advocate for junior women faculty in the college. She plans to continue her work providing networking opportunities and encouraging discussions among women mathematicians, especially junior women mathematicians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inequalities for the eigenvalues of the sum of two selfadjoint matrices had been studied for a long time, starting with H. Weyl in 1912.
In 1962, A. Horn gave an ingenious conjecture, a collection of inequalities among the eigenvalues of two selfadjoint matrices and their sum that would characterize the relation sum.  The subject has a rich century long history and the tools that are used to study the question ranging from algebraic geometry to representation theory to combinatorics to analysis, especially during the last twenty years or so, the subject attracted some of the most brilliant mathematicians of our time, including Terrance Tao. It is only in the late 1990s the conjecture was settled positively, using techniques from algebraic geometry, intersection theory, representation theory, and some very clever combinatorics. This led to
significant progress in representation theory and algebraic geometry. For the past 15 years, it has been an on going project of H. Bercovici and the PI to understand the theory from an analysis point of view and generalize the results to infinite dimensional settings, including selfadjoint compact operators, and selfadjoint operators in finite type II factors. Eight years ago the PI and her collaborators made a breakthrough in the search of a constructive proof of the conjecture that can be extended to infinite dimensional setting. Since then they have made significant progress and obtain some rather surprising results that generalized finite dimensional results to infinite dimensional settings. The progress of our work will bring new insights and connections into operator algebra, algebraic geometry, and operator theory. During the course of our study, new questions arise and their answers will bring new understanding to the structure of selfadjoint  operators and the structure of operator semigroups.

 

There is a very important aspect of this project that relates to human resources. The PI was the Georgia Tech ADVANCE Professor in College of Sciences. She spent a significant amount of her time and energy to foster a network among women faculty in the college, promoting women faculty's advancement, promoting a more family friendly working environment, and working together with other ADVANCE Professors on campus and institute leaderships to promote diversity. The progress in the project allows her to lead through scientific excellency.
